Synaptipy
  • Synaptipy User Tutorial and Documentation
  • Edit on GitHub

Synaptipy User Tutorial and DocumentationÔÉÅ

Synaptipy is a comprehensive electrophysiology visualization and analysis suite for patch-clamp and intracellular recording data. Built on Python and Qt6, it provides high-performance signal visualization, 14 dedicated analysis modules, a batch processing engine, and standards-compliant data export. This tutorial covers every feature of the application in detail, including the mathematical methods used under the hood.

Table of ContentsÔÉÅ

  1. The Explorer Tab

  2. Signal Preprocessing

  3. The Analyser Tab

  4. Analysis Modules ‚Äî Detailed Reference

    • 4.1 Baseline / RMP

    • 4.2 Spike Detection

    • 4.3 Event Detection ‚Äî Threshold Based

    • 4.4 Event Detection ‚Äî Template Match

    • 4.5 Event Detection ‚Äî Baseline Peak

    • 4.6 Input Resistance

    • 4.7 Tau (Time Constant)

    • 4.8 I-V Curve

    • 4.9 Burst Analysis

    • 4.10 Capacitance

    • 4.11 Excitability (F-I Curve)

    • 4.12 Optogenetic Synchronization

    • 4.13 Phase Plane Analysis

    • 4.14 Spike Train Dynamics

  5. Batch Processing

  6. The Exporter Tab

  7. Preferences and Customization

1. The Explorer TabÔÉÅ

The Explorer tab is the starting point for loading, browsing, and inspecting electrophysiology data files. It supports all formats handled by the Neo library (.abf, .smr, .smrx, .nex, .h5, and many more).

1.1 File SidebarÔÉÅ

  • File System Tree ‚Äî A live tree filtered to supported electrophysiology extensions. Click any file to load it instantly.

  • Project Tree ‚Äî Groups recordings hierarchically by Animal ‚Üí Slice ‚Üí Cell. Supports multi-selection for batch operations.

  • Drag & Drop ‚Äî Drag files from the OS file manager directly into the sidebar.

  • Quality Indicator ‚Äî Traffic-light badge per file:

    • Green Good ‚Äî Clean signal, low drift, acceptable SNR.

    • Yellow Warning ‚Äî Moderate baseline drift or line noise detected.

    • Red Bad ‚Äî Excessive noise, drift, or signal quality issues. Hover to see detailed metrics: RMS noise, drift rate, and specific warnings.

1.2 Plot CanvasÔÉÅ

  • Multi-Channel Display ‚Äî Each channel is plotted on a separate axis with linked X-axes for synchronized panning/zooming.

  • Hardware-Accelerated Rendering ‚Äî PyQtGraph + OpenGL, up to 60 fps on large files.

  • Interactive Navigation ‚Äî Scroll to zoom, drag to pan, toolbar for fine control.

1.3 Display Configuration PanelÔÉÅ

  • Plot Mode

    • Overlay All + Average ‚Äî All trials with average highlighted in bold.

    • Cycle Single Trial ‚Äî One trial at a time with Prev/Next buttons.

  • Auto Downsample ‚Äî Reduces data density automatically for very large files.

  • Manual Trial Averaging (Cycle mode) ‚Äî Add Current Trial / Clear Average / Plot Selected Average.

  • Trial Selection ‚Äî Trial Gap (skip N) and Start Trial index for sub-sampling.

  • Channel Visibility ‚Äî Per-channel show/hide checkboxes.

  • Live Spike Detection ‚Äî Real-time detection with configurable threshold (default ‚àí20 mV) and refractory period (default 2 ms). Spikes shown as red dots.

1.4 ToolbarÔÉÅ

  • Prev / Next File ‚Äî Navigate through all files in the directory.

  • Save Plot ‚Äî Export the current view to PNG or PDF.

  • Reset View ‚Äî Restore default zoom and position.

  • Lock Zoom ‚Äî Preserve the viewport when switching files (useful for cross-file comparison of the same time window).

  • X Zoom Slider ‚Äî Fine horizontal zoom control.

  • Prev / Next Trial (Cycle mode) ‚Äî Navigate individual sweeps.

1.5 Y-Axis ControlsÔÉÅ

  • Lock Y Views ‚Äî Link or unlink Y-axes across channels.

  • Global Y Controls (locked) ‚Äî Single slider + scroll bar for all channels.

  • Per-Channel Y Controls (unlocked) ‚Äî Independent slider + scroll bar per channel. All controls are debounced (50 ms) for smooth interaction.

1.6 Adding Data to the AnalyserÔÉÅ

Click ‚ÄúAdd to Analysis Set‚Äù to send the loaded file to the Analyser tab‚Äôs queue.

2. Signal PreprocessingÔÉÅ

A unified preprocessing panel is available in both the Explorer and Analyser tabs. Preprocessing applied in any analysis sub-tab propagates globally to all sub-tabs.

2.1 Digital FiltersÔÉÅ

All filters use zero-phase Butterworth IIR via scipy.signal.sosfiltfilt (no phase distortion).

Filter

Parameters

Description

Lowpass

Cutoff (Hz), Order

Remove high-frequency noise

Highpass

Cutoff (Hz), Order

Remove slow baseline drift

Bandpass

Low & High cutoff (Hz), Order

Pass a specific frequency band

Notch

Center (Hz), Q-factor

Remove a narrow band (e.g., 50/60 Hz mains) ‚Äî scipy.signal.iirnotch

Comb

Base freq (Hz), Q, N harmonics

Cascaded notch filters removing a fundamental and all harmonics

2.2 Baseline Subtraction MethodsÔÉÅ

Method

Description

Mode

Subtract statistical mode (configurable decimal precision)

Mean

Subtract full-trace arithmetic mean

Median

Subtract full-trace median

Linear Detrend

Fit and remove a linear trend via scipy.signal.detrend

Time Window

Subtract mean of a user-specified region [t_start, t_end]

2.3 Trace Quality AssessmentÔÉÅ

Computed on file load; shown as a traffic-light badge with tooltip:

  • SNR ‚Äî signal power / noise power.

  • Baseline Drift ‚Äî linear regression slope over the full trace (mV/s).

  • Line Noise ‚Äî Welch PSD at 50/60 Hz.

  • Low-Frequency Variance ‚Äî energy below a configurable cutoff.

3. The Analyser TabÔÉÅ

The central analysis engine. All 14 analysis sub-tabs are auto-built from registry metadata ‚Äî parameter widgets, interactive plots, and result tables are generated automatically.

3.1 File and Data Source SelectionÔÉÅ

  • File Selector ‚Äî All files in the analysis set.

  • Channel Selector ‚Äî Choose the channel to analyze. Clamp mode (CC / VC) is auto-detected from channel units and controls which parameters appear.

  • Data Source ‚Äî Average (mean of all trials), Trial 1, Trial 2, etc.

  • Drag-and-Drop File List ‚Äî Drop files directly from the Explorer sidebar.

3.2 Analysis Sub-Tab FeaturesÔÉÅ

Each sub-tab provides:

  • Parameter Panel ‚Äî Auto-generated spin boxes, combo boxes, and checkboxes. All include tooltips, unit suffixes, valid min/max ranges.

  • Interactive Plot

    • Draggable Regions ‚Äî Color-coded overlays (blue = baseline, red = response, orange = peak, green = steady-state) bidirectionally linked to parameter boxes.

    • Interactive Event Markers ‚Äî Click to remove; Ctrl+click on trace to add.

    • Draggable Threshold Line ‚Äî Syncs with the threshold parameter.

    • Artifact Overlay ‚Äî Semi-transparent green shading on detected artifact windows.

    • Fit Overlays ‚Äî Exponential or regression curves overlaid on the trace.

  • Results Table ‚Äî Parameter / Value pairs for all computed metrics.

  • Clamp-Mode Awareness ‚Äî Parameters show/hide automatically (CC vs. VC).

3.3 Shared ControlsÔÉÅ

  • Run Analysis ‚Äî Executes with current parameters; also auto-triggers (debounced) on parameter change.

  • Save Result ‚Äî Accumulate result to the session for later export/comparison.

  • Copy Methods Text ‚Äî Publication-ready methods paragraph copied to clipboard.

  • Run Batch ‚Äî Opens the Batch Analysis Dialog (see Section 5).

  • Cross-Tab Zoom Sync ‚Äî Zoom states shared across all analysis sub-tabs.

3.4 Popup WindowsÔÉÅ

  • I-V Curve popup ‚Äî Scatter + linear regression with R¬≤ annotation.

  • F-I Curve popup ‚Äî Firing frequency vs. current with regression.

  • Phase Plane popup ‚Äî dV/dt vs. V with threshold circles and max-dV/dt crosses.

  • ISI Plot popup ‚Äî ISI number vs. ISI duration scatter.

3.5 Session SummaryÔÉÅ

Shows all accumulated results with Mean ¬± SD for numeric columns across cells.

4. Analysis Modules ‚Äî Detailed ReferenceÔÉÅ

4.1 Baseline / RMP AnalysisÔÉÅ

Registry name: rmp_analysis | Tab label: Baseline (RMP)

Computes resting membrane potential and baseline stability.

ParametersÔÉÅ

Parameter

Type

Description

Baseline Start

float (s)

Start of baseline window

Baseline End

float (s)

End of baseline window

Auto Detect

bool

Find most stable window automatically

Window Duration

float (s)

Sliding window size (auto mode)

Step Duration

float (s)

Sliding window step (auto mode)

MethodsÔÉÅ

  • RMP = mean voltage in baseline window.

  • SD bounds = RMP ¬± std(baseline).

  • Drift = linear regression slope (mV/s).

  • Auto-detect: find_stable_baseline() uses sliding-window variance minimization to locate the quietest trace segment.

ResultsÔÉÅ

rmp_mv, rmp_std, rmp_mv_plus_sd, rmp_mv_minus_sd, rmp_drift, rmp_duration

VisualizationÔÉÅ

Green draggable region; solid red h-line at RMP; dashed red h-lines at ¬±SD.

4.2 Spike DetectionÔÉÅ

Registry name: spike_detection | Tab label: Spike Detection

Automated detection and comprehensive parameterization of action potentials.

ParametersÔÉÅ

Parameter

Type

Description

Threshold

float (mV)

Detection threshold (default ‚àí20 mV)

Refractory Period

float (s)

Minimum inter-spike interval (default 2 ms)

Peak Search Window

float (s)

Post-threshold window to find peak

dV/dt Threshold

float (V/s)

Derivative threshold for onset

AHP Window

float (s)

Post-peak window for AHP minimum

Onset Lookback

float (s)

Lookback for onset refinement

MethodsÔÉÅ

  • Onset ‚Äî numpy.gradient computes dV/dt; onset where dV/dt > dvdt_threshold. More robust against baseline drift than amplitude thresholding.

  • Per-spike features (vectorized NumPy):

    • Amplitude = V_peak ‚àí V_threshold

    • Half-width at 50% amplitude (linear interpolation)

    • Rise time 10‚Äì90%, Decay time 90‚Äì10% (sub-sample precision)

    • AHP depth = V_threshold ‚àí V_min_post (Savitzky-Golay smoothed)

    • AHP duration = repolarization to AHP recovery

    • ADP amplitude = local max after AHP trough

    • Max / Min dV/dt (V/s)

  • ISI statistics via numpy.diff(spike_times).

  • Multi-sweep: analyze_multi_sweep_spikes() aggregates across all trials.

ResultsÔÉÅ

spike_count, mean_freq_hz, spike_times, mean ¬± SD for: amplitude, half_width, rise_time, decay_time, ahp_depth, ahp_duration, adp_amplitude, max_dvdt, min_dvdt

VisualizationÔÉÅ

Red dashed threshold h-line; red dot markers at spike peaks.

4.3 Event Detection ‚Äî Threshold BasedÔÉÅ

Registry name: event_detection_threshold | Tab label: Event Detection

Detects mEPSCs / mIPSCs using adaptive prominence-based thresholding. A method selector dropdown switches between all three event detection algorithms (sections 4.3 ‚Äì 4.5).

ParametersÔÉÅ

Parameter

Type

Description

Threshold

float (pA/mV)

Minimum event amplitude

Direction

combo

negative or positive

Refractory Period

float (s)

Minimum inter-event interval

Rolling Baseline Window

float (ms)

Rolling median baseline window

Reject Artifacts

bool

Gradient-based artifact rejection

Artifact Slope Threshold

float

Gradient threshold for artifacts

Artifact Padding

float (ms)

Dilation padding around artifacts

MethodsÔÉÅ

  1. Rolling median subtraction removes slow drift.

  2. MAD noise estimate: œÉ = 1.4826 √ó MAD.

  3. Adaptive prominence = max(threshold, 2œÉ).

  4. scipy.signal.find_peaks with prominence, height, refractory distance, and min-width constraints. Events < 0.2 ms rejected as non-physiological.

  5. Artifact rejection: gradient thresholding + asymmetric binary dilation.

ResultsÔÉÅ

event_count, frequency_hz, mean_amplitude, amplitude_sd, event_times, event_indices, event_amplitudes

VisualizationÔÉÅ

Interactive scatter markers (click to remove; Ctrl+click to add); draggable threshold line; artifact overlay.

4.4 Event Detection ‚Äî Template Match / DeconvolutionÔÉÅ

Registry name: event_detection_deconvolution | Tab label: Event (Template Match)

Detects events via a matched-filter approach using a bi-exponential template.

ParametersÔÉÅ

Parameter

Type

Description

œÑ Rise

float (ms)

Rise time constant

œÑ Decay

float (ms)

Decay time constant

Threshold (SD)

float

Z-score detection threshold

Direction

combo

Event polarity

Rolling Baseline Window

float (ms)

Baseline subtraction window

Reject Artifacts

bool

Enable artifact rejection

Min Event Distance

float (ms)

Minimum event separation

MethodsÔÉÅ

  1. Bi-exponential kernel: K(t) = exp(‚àít/œÑ_decay) ‚àí exp(‚àít/œÑ_rise), normalized.

  2. FFT cross-correlation (matched filter) with the time-reversed template.

  3. Z-score normalization by MAD; peaks above threshold_sd are events.

  4. Local argmax refinement aligns detected times to true event peaks.

ResultsÔÉÅ

Same as threshold method plus tau_rise_ms, tau_decay_ms.

VisualizationÔÉÅ

Same interactive markers / threshold line / artifact overlay.

4.5 Event Detection ‚Äî Baseline Peak / KineticsÔÉÅ

Registry name: event_detection_baseline_peak | Tab label: Event (Baseline Peak)

Detects events by finding the most stable baseline and locating peaks above the noise floor.

ParametersÔÉÅ

Parameter

Type

Description

Direction

combo

Event polarity

Auto Baseline

bool

Variance-minimization baseline search

Threshold (SD Factor)

float

Multiples of noise SD

Min Event Separation

float (ms)

Minimum inter-event gap

Rolling Baseline Window

float (ms)

Rolling baseline size

Baseline Window

float (s)

Manual window (if auto disabled)

Baseline Step

float (s)

Manual step size

MethodsÔÉÅ

  1. Stable baseline via sliding-window variance minimization.

  2. MAD noise estimate from baseline region.

  3. Prominence-based peaks, min prominence = 0.5 √ó threshold.

  4. Optional Butterworth lowpass pre-filter.

  5. Biological minimum event width ‚â• 0.2 ms.

ResultsÔÉÅ

event_count, event_indices, event_times, event_amplitudes

4.6 Input Resistance (Rin)ÔÉÅ

Registry name: rin_analysis | Tab label: Input Resistance

Computes passive membrane input resistance from step protocols.

ParametersÔÉÅ

Parameter

Type

Description

Current Amplitude

float (pA)

CC mode step (hidden in VC)

Voltage Step

float (mV)

VC mode step (hidden in CC)

Auto Detect Pulse

bool

Derivative-based pulse edge detection

Baseline Start / End

float (s)

Baseline window

Response Start / End

float (s)

Steady-state window

MethodsÔÉÅ

  • Ohm‚Äôs Law: Rin (MŒ©) = |ŒîV| / |ŒîI|, where ŒîV = V_ss ‚àí V_baseline.

  • Conductance: G (ŒºS) = ŒîI / ŒîV.

  • Auto-detection uses the derivative of the stimulus channel to find step edges.

ResultsÔÉÅ

rin_mohm, conductance_us, voltage_deflection_mv, current_injection_pa, baseline_voltage_mv, steady_state_voltage_mv

VisualizationÔÉÅ

Blue region (baseline) + red region (response); blue h-line at baseline voltage; red h-line at steady-state voltage.

4.7 Tau (Membrane Time Constant)ÔÉÅ

Registry name: tau_analysis | Tab label: Tau (Time Constant)

Fits the membrane charging curve to extract the passive time constant.

ParametersÔÉÅ

Parameter

Type

Description

Stim Start Time

float (s)

Current step onset

Fit Duration

float (s)

Duration of decay region to fit

Tau Model

combo

mono or bi exponential

Artifact Blanking

float (ms)

Exclude N ms after stimulus onset

Tau Bound Min / Max

float (ms)

Bounds for œÑ optimizer

MethodsÔÉÅ

  • Mono: V(t) = V_ss + (V_0 ‚àí V_ss) ¬∑ exp(‚àít/œÑ), optimized via scipy.optimize.curve_fit (bounded non-linear least squares).

  • Bi: V(t) = V_ss + A_fast ¬∑ exp(‚àít/œÑ_fast) + A_slow ¬∑ exp(‚àít/œÑ_slow), separating fast capacitive from slower dendritic components.

  • Artifact blanking excludes the first N ms after stimulus onset.

ResultsÔÉÅ

Mono: tau_ms. Bi: tau_fast_ms, tau_slow_ms, amp_fast, amp_slow. Plus fit_time and fit_values for the overlay.

VisualizationÔÉÅ

Red exponential fit curve overlaid on the raw voltage trace.

4.8 I-V CurveÔÉÅ

Registry name: iv_curve_analysis | Tab label: I-V Curve Requires multiple trials (multi-sweep step protocol).

ParametersÔÉÅ

Parameter

Type

Description

Start Current

float (pA)

Current of sweep 0

Step Current

float (pA)

Current increment per sweep

Baseline Start / End

float (s)

Baseline measurement window

Response Start / End

float (s)

Steady-state measurement window

MethodsÔÉÅ

  • Per sweep n: I_n = I_start + n √ó I_step; ŒîV_n = mean(V_response) ‚àí mean(V_baseline).

  • Linear regression ŒîV vs. ŒîI: slope = Rin (MŒ©), R¬≤ = goodness of fit.

ResultsÔÉÅ

rin_aggregate_mohm, iv_intercept, iv_r_squared, delta_vs, current_steps

VisualizationÔÉÅ

Popup I-V scatter + linear regression line with slope annotation and R¬≤.

4.9 Burst AnalysisÔÉÅ

Registry name: burst_analysis | Tab label: Burst

Identifies firing bursts based on inter-spike interval (ISI) criteria.

ParametersÔÉÅ

Parameter

Type

Description

Threshold

float (mV)

Spike detection threshold

Max ISI (Start)

float (s)

Maximum ISI to start a burst

Max ISI (End)

float (s)

Maximum ISI to continue a burst

Min Spikes

int

Minimum spikes per burst

MethodsÔÉÅ

  1. Threshold-crossing spike detection.

  2. ISI-based detector: burst starts when ISI ‚â§ max_isi_start; continues while ISI ‚â§ max_isi_end; groups with < min_spikes are discarded.

ResultsÔÉÅ

burst_count, spikes_per_burst_avg, burst_duration_avg_s, burst_freq_hz, bursts

VisualizationÔÉÅ

Red bracket lines spanning each burst, with spike markers inside each burst.

4.10 CapacitanceÔÉÅ

Registry name: capacitance_analysis | Tab label: Capacitance

Estimates whole-cell membrane capacitance from step protocols.

ParametersÔÉÅ

Parameter

Type

Description

Mode

combo

Current-Clamp or Voltage-Clamp

Current Amplitude

float (pA)

Step size (CC mode)

Voltage Step

float (mV)

Step size (VC mode)

Baseline Start / End

float (s)

Baseline window

Response Start / End

float (s)

Response window

MethodsÔÉÅ

  • CC mode: C_m = œÑ / R_in. Tau and Rin computed first; œÑ(ms) / R(MŒ©) ‚Üí C(pF).

  • VC mode: C_m = Q / ŒîV, where Q = ‚à´(I_transient ‚àí I_ss) dt via scipy.integrate.trapezoid.

ResultsÔÉÅ

capacitance_pf, tau_ms, rin_mohm, mode

4.11 Excitability (F-I Curve)ÔÉÅ

Registry name: excitability_analysis | Tab label: Excitability Requires multiple trials (increasing current-step protocol).

ParametersÔÉÅ

Parameter

Type

Description

Threshold

float (mV)

Spike detection threshold

Start Current

float (pA)

Current of sweep 0

Step Current

float (pA)

Current increment per sweep

Refractory Period

float (ms)

Refractory period for spike detection

MethodsÔÉÅ

  1. Per-sweep spike detection with threshold + refractory filtering.

  2. Rheobase = minimum current eliciting ‚â• 1 spike.

  3. F-I slope via linear regression: f = slope √ó I + b (Hz/pA).

  4. Spike Frequency Adaptation per sweep = last ISI / first ISI.

ResultsÔÉÅ

rheobase_pa, fi_slope, fi_r_squared, max_freq_hz, frequencies, adaptation_ratios, current_steps

VisualizationÔÉÅ

Popup F-I scatter with regression line and slope annotation.

4.12 Optogenetic SynchronizationÔÉÅ

Registry name: optogenetic_sync | Tab label: Optogenetic Synchronization Requires secondary TTL channel (dropdown to select the optical stimulus channel).

ParametersÔÉÅ

Parameter

Type

Description

TTL Threshold

float (V)

Binarize threshold for TTL channel

Response Window

float (ms)

Post-stimulus spike search window

Spike Threshold

float (mV)

AP detection threshold

MethodsÔÉÅ

  1. TTL edge detection: binarize ‚Üí numpy.diff for rising edges. Auto-threshold applied if specified value fails.

  2. Per-stimulus: detect first AP within response window.

  3. Optical latency = mean(t_spike ‚àí t_onset).

  4. Response probability = stimuli_with_spikes / total_stimuli.

  5. Jitter = std(latencies).

ResultsÔÉÅ

optical_latency_ms, response_probability, spike_jitter_ms, stimulus_count, stimulus_onsets

VisualizationÔÉÅ

Spike markers on voltage trace; cyan dashed vertical lines at TTL onsets.

4.13 Phase Plane AnalysisÔÉÅ

Registry name: phase_plane_analysis | Tab label: Phase Plane

Visualizes AP dynamics in phase space (dV/dt vs. V).

ParametersÔÉÅ

Parameter

Type

Description

Sigma

float (ms)

Gaussian smoothing for dV/dt

dV/dt Threshold

float (V/s)

Phase-plane crossing threshold

Spike Threshold

float (mV)

Voltage threshold for spike detection

Kink Slope

float

dV/dt value defining initiation ‚Äúkink‚Äù

Search Window

float (ms)

Lookback window for kink detection

MethodsÔÉÅ

  1. dV/dt via numpy.gradient + scipy.ndimage.gaussian_filter1d.

  2. Phase-plane trajectory = V(t) vs. dV/dt(t).

  3. Kink detection: first point where dV/dt crosses kink_slope in the lookback window before the spike peak ‚Äî reflects axonal AP initiation.

  4. Max dV/dt = peak upstroke velocity.

ResultsÔÉÅ

voltage, dvdt arrays; threshold_indices, threshold_v, threshold_dvdt, threshold_mean, max_dvdt

VisualizationÔÉÅ

Popup phase-plane plot: red circles at threshold, green crosses at max dV/dt. H-line on main trace at threshold voltage.

4.14 Spike Train DynamicsÔÉÅ

Registry name: train_dynamics | Tab label: Spike Train Dynamics

Quantifies spike train regularity and temporal structure with ISI statistics.

ParametersÔÉÅ

Parameter

Type

Description

Spike Threshold

float (mV)

AP detection threshold

MethodsÔÉÅ

  1. ISI = numpy.diff(spike_times).

  2. CV = œÉ_ISI / Œº_ISI ‚Äî global variability (0 = regular, 1 = Poisson).

  3. CV‚ÇÇ (Holt et al. 1996) = mean(2|ISI_(i+1) ‚àí ISI_i| / (ISI_(i+1) + ISI_i)) ‚Äî local variability, insensitive to slow rate changes.

  4. LV (Shinomoto et al. 2003) = mean(3(ISI_i ‚àí ISI_(i+1))¬≤ / (ISI_i + ISI_(i+1))¬≤) ‚Äî LV < 1 regular, LV ‚âà 1 Poisson, LV > 1 bursty.

ResultsÔÉÅ

spike_count, mean_isi_s, cv, cv2, lv, isi_numbers, isi_ms

VisualizationÔÉÅ

Spike markers on the voltage trace; popup ISI-number vs. ISI-duration scatter.

5. Batch ProcessingÔÉÅ

5.1 OverviewÔÉÅ

The batch engine applies an analysis pipeline across many files automatically, producing a consolidated Pandas DataFrame result.

5.2 Opening the Batch DialogÔÉÅ

Click ‚ÄúRun Batch‚Äù in the Analyser tab toolbar. The dialog shows:

  • The file list from the analysis set.

  • A visual pipeline builder.

  • A progress bar and status label.

5.3 Building a PipelineÔÉÅ

  1. Add Step ‚Äî select from all 14 registered analyses.

  2. Scope ‚Äî Average, All Trials, First Trial, Specific Trial, or Channel Set.

  3. Configure Parameters with auto-generated widgets.

  4. Optionally prepend Preprocessing Steps (filter / baseline-subtract).

5.4 Running and CancellationÔÉÅ

A background worker thread processes each file sequentially with per-file progress updates. Click Cancel at any time via a thread-safe flag.

5.5 OutputÔÉÅ

DataFrame columns: file_name, file_path, channel, analysis, scope + all analysis-specific result keys. Displayed in-dialog and exportable to CSV.

6. The Exporter TabÔÉÅ

6.1 NWB ExportÔÉÅ

Click ‚ÄúExport to NWB‚Äù to open the NWB Metadata Dialog (four tabs):

  • Session ‚Äî description, UUID (auto-generated), start time, experimenter, lab, institution.

  • Subject ‚Äî ID, species, age (ISO 8601), sex, genotype, weight.

  • Device ‚Äî name, description, manufacturer.

  • Electrodes ‚Äî description, location, filtering.

Produces a .nwb file with raw traces, metadata, and extracted features ‚Äî fully NWB-compliant.

6.2 Analysis Results ExportÔÉÅ

  • Table: Analysis Type, Source File, Data Source, Value, Timestamp, Details.

  • Select/deselect individual results with checkboxes.

  • Refresh Results syncs with the latest session accumulation.

  • Export to CSV (R, MATLAB, Python) or JSON (nested structure).

6.3 Plot ExportÔÉÅ

Every Explorer and Analyser sub-tab has a ‚ÄúSave Plot‚Äù button:

  • Format: PNG or PDF.

  • DPI setting for publication-quality figures.

7. Preferences and CustomizationÔÉÅ

7.1 Preferences Dialog (Edit ‚Üí Preferences)ÔÉÅ

  • Scroll Behavior ‚Äî Natural, Inverted, or System.

  • Appearance ‚Äî Light, Dark, or System theme with live preview.

7.2 Plot Customization Dialog (View ‚Üí Plot Customization)ÔÉÅ

  • Average Trace ‚Äî color, line width, opacity.

  • Single Trial ‚Äî color, line width, opacity + ‚ÄúForce Opaque‚Äù toggle for faster rendering on large datasets.

  • Grid ‚Äî grid line customization.

  • Each tab includes Reset to Defaults.

7.3 Analysis Defaults (Edit ‚Üí Configure Analysis Defaults)ÔÉÅ

Registry parameter editor ‚Äî modify default values for any analysis module. Changes persist across sessions.

Appendix A: Supported File FormatsÔÉÅ

Format

Extensions

Axon ABF

.abf

Spike2

.smr, .smrx

NeuroExplorer

.nex

HDF5 / NWB

.h5, .nwb

Axon ATF

.atf

Igor Pro

.ibw, .pxp

And many more

See Neo documentation

Appendix B: ArchitectureÔÉÅ

Layer

Responsibility

Technologies

Core

Signal processing, analysis algorithms

NumPy, SciPy, pure Python

Application

GUI, user interaction, visualization

PySide6, PyQtGraph

Infrastructure

File I/O, format adapters

Neo, PyNWB

The Registry Pattern (AnalysisRegistry) provides plugin-style extensibility: any script decorated with @AnalysisRegistry.register automatically becomes a new analysis sub-tab in the GUI.
